newsitem.title: ITALY: ENI doesn't need capital increase - Bernabe.
newsitem.headline: ENI doesn't need capital increase - Bernabe.

text.p: Italy energy giant ENI does not need a capital increase as its group debt has already been cut to a satisfactory level, managing director Franco Bernabe said.

ENI..."does not need a capital increase, the debt has already been reduced sufficiently," Bernabe told reporters after a presentation to analysts on the second tranche of shares to be offered to investors.
The group expects the ratio between debt and shareholders equity to fall from the 0.60 percent level seen at June 30, when the group's debt was 15.078 trillion lire.

The Italian Treasury announced that it was offering 700 million shares amounting to 8.75 percent of the share capital to investors later this month, after it had offered 15 percent in a first tranche in late 1995.
"But the Treasury said this morning that the demand will be superior, and will consider increasing the offer," Bernabe said.

Treasury Director Mario Draghi said earlier today that the 8.75 percent of the share capital, but nearly 10 percent of the group including the green shoe amount, could be increased if demand was strong enough.
The Italian offer is set to open on October 21, the price set on October 26 and trading in the new shares to start on October 28.
